note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.
John Jones Pettus belonged to the following social groups:
John Gill Shorter was governor of Alabama during the first half of the Civil War.

Born on April 23, 1818, in Monticello, Georgia, Shorter graduated from the University of Georgia in 1837 and then moved to Alabama, where his family had settled a few years earlier. The Shorters gradually purchased land in Barbour County, Alabama, becoming one of the wealthiest families in the area. Shorter became a practicing attorney and opened a successful law firm with a brother in Alabama.

In the early 1840s, Shorter became active in Democratic politics and in 1845 won a seat in the Alabama Senate. He served a single term, and then won a seat in the Alabama House of Representatives in 1851. However, he left the House before the end of his term when he received an appointment as circuit judge. He served as a judge through the 1850s, but continued to be involved in politics. Like most other southern leaders of the time, Shorter was strongly pro-slavery, advocating the institution’s expansion westward. He initially was not a vocal proponent of secession, but supported financial policies that boosted the south’s independence from the northern economy.

When Abraham Lincoln won the presidential election in 1860, Shorter endorsed secession. The governor of Alabama, Andrew B. Moore, appointed Shorter a secession commissioner to Georgia, tasked with recruiting that state to secede and join a southern confederacy. He then won a seat in the Provisional Confederate Congress and helped write a constitution for the Confederate States of America. In August 1861, Shorter successfully ran for governor Alabama. Although he had long advocated states’ rights, the realities of war against a larger, more powerful Union led Shorter to adopt policies that countered his pre-war principles. He supported the Confederate government’s military draft, and he urged the Alabama legislature to pass a law that allowed him to impress slaves, from Alabama slaveowners, to work on state and military projects. These policies and other wartime events outraged many southerners, and resulted in Shorter’s popularity sharply declining while in office. He lost reelection in 1863.

After the expiration of his term, Shorter returned to his home in Eufaula, Alabama, and practiced law until he died on May 29, 1872. He was married to Mary Jane Battle. Shorter is buried in Shorter Cemetery in Eufala, Alabama.
John Gill Shorter belonged to the following social groups:
Prairie Point is located in Noxubee County, Mississippi.
Located in Noxubee County, Macon was founded on August 10, 1835, and serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia; Dunbar Rowland, Mississippi, Vol. 2, pg. 158)

Currently located in Lowndes County, Columbus was founded on December 6, 1819 in what was then a "non-county area." When Lowndes County was created on January 30, 1830, Columbus became its county seat. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
The Territory of Alabama was established March 3, 1817. Admitted as the 22nd state, Alabama achieved statehood December 14, 1819. (Encyclopedia of Alabama; Wikipedia)

gloss.p: "A person or a company that makes strong alcoholic drinks by the process of distilling," which the Cambridge Dictionary defines as "The process of making a liquid stronger or purer by heating it until it changes to a gas and then cooling it so that it changes back into a liquid, or a liquid made by this process." (Cambridge Dictionary)

element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Pettus Collection. Letter from John D. Bush in Prairie Point, Mississippi, to Mississippi Governor John J. Pettus, asking for permission to make corn whiskey to sell to the Confederate Army for medical purposes.

div.p: My object in writing to you is to ascertain if there has been any law passed in this state prohibiting the stilling of corn into whiskey, If the such a law has been passed, will you give me permission to make whiskey by my, selling at $5, per gallon, and for medical purposes only, If you will allow me to make it at that price for medical purposes, If I can get stills (which I think I can do) I am willing to sell to the Confederacy, and deliver it at $5, per gallon at Macon Depot, or at Columbus, Owing to the scarscity of whiskey, speculators have put it up to from $8 to $25, per gallon; I have paid that for it myself, for medical purposes, and I do think it an outrage upon the community. The Governor of Alabama allows whiskey to be made in that state for medical purposes, and I think it should be so in every state in the Confederacy, I think it would keep down speculation and Drunkenness &c, If you will give me permission to make it, and I succeed in getting stills, I am willing to sell all I can make to you, for the Confederacy, and deliver it at either of the above named places, Please write me as soon as suits your conveniance, and you will Greatly Oblige Your Obedient Servant &c
N. B. Direct your response to, Prarie Point,
Mr Bush wishes to know if there has been any law passed prohibiting the making of whiskey, The waste to make it for the government for $5 per gallon
